author: eskimoid
body:
I think you are wrong on all three. The two biggest players in the glass industry are Guardian Glass and Cardinal Glass Industries both of which are privately owned. Both of these companies make the float glass, temper it, and then put it in laminated frames. They they sell this glass to companies like JELD that puts it in framesand then sells it to the consumer for residential projects. For larger projects contractors buy this glass to put it in buildings they are building.

PPG doesn't even make glass anymore. They only make paint. Their glass sector looks like it was bought by Vitro and is traded on MXN.

You literally have corning in there. They make specialty glass as in glass that does not go in commercial or residential buildings.

author: TheTigersAreNotReal
body: So I had unintentionally tried to deposit too much money into my account two weeks ago and it was returned by my bank. I sold out of my positions last Thursday to pay off the margin call, and I’m restricted until I can deposit the actual amount into my account. One of my positions I sold was a bunch of GLW 24c that I had bought at 0.11 and sold at 0.5. On Friday those calls dropped down to 0.22. I wanted to buy back in but I couldn’t. Now they’re at over 0.6. If I hadn’t been so stupid I could’ve already tripled my money. Instead I’m sitting in cash, unable to buy, shedding a tear for missed tendies.

author: w1na
body:
She did a good job, no one could even imagine even 5 years ago where AMD would be today.
When she took office, the cupboard were bare, there was no sales, no good architecture, losing for 2 decade to intel. Since the first athlon x64, they kept releasing bad products most of the time. In just 3 years, she made AMD go from Zero to Hero!

AMD now trading at tremendous numbers, no one thought would be possible ever. Heck just look 7 years back, the share price was about 2 bucks.

If there is any CEO who you feel should earn so much, it’s not people from Moderna, but Lisa Su.

Just to give you an idea, back in 2014 or so, I remember trying to buy AMD shares under 2 euros each (I wanted to get 2000 euro), before the order went through, it asked me for some paperwork confirmation, I then did not go through with the order and never did.

Missed on 1000 shares from AMD. I did not believe back then, although I saw it was incredibly cheap.

author: mechtech
body:
Well this is /r/investing, so buy quality and hold, diversify (beyond just bonds which may or may not have a good future in a zero rate world), and have worldwide exposure/don't arbitrarily lock yourself to your own country.

I actively trade, but in all likelihood in 2040 the investors at the top will likely have stories like "As Waymo got bigger, my ETF kept buying more, and now Waymo is 10 trillion dollars. And as that Chinese electric car company grew and took 1/3 of the 1 billion person Chinese market, my ETF kept buying more on the way up."

Although in that same vein, getting ahead of the tech curve might be one of the few ways for someone outside of the professional investor/institutional world to realistically get ahead. The trick is having the fortitude to hold for 1-2 decades. The financial crisis in '08 blew me out of so many hilariously good positions, like SBAC because the iPhone was just invented and 3G means more cell phone towers... It's not always rocket science. Anyone with some specialized insight into the future, whatever it may be, should consider putting a small well thought out speculative position on and leave it be. Small enough to not hurt if it goes nowhere, but big enough to care enough to check up and manage every few months.

Wow, just looked up an email from over 10 years ago. These names are probably in the mainstream investing language now, but wow... 10-100x if they were held. And it wasn't complex quant investing or anything, just looking ahead, positioning, and waiting.

Quotes from the email circa 10 years ago: "NVDA... They are also making a leap into scientific computing, where there's a lot of money to be made. They're the first major player to enter that arena to fight Intel and AMD in a long time, and their architecture is much more suited to scientific computing than the traditional CPUs that currently rule the top 100 supercomputer list. I think I'll see how that works out before selling NVDA"

"I might want to put some money in AMD as well. They're here to stay and may still be undervalued..."

"Universal Display Corp and LG Display (PANL/LPL) are also the leaders and partners in OLED screen development, which is bound to catch on eventually. Lower power use and much better image quality mean that it's just a matter of time before more devices adopt this new display technology and it becomes a new standard. I actually expect Apple to eventually partner up with LG (I think LG is their main LCD supplier) and use and use an OLED display on either a new product or a new Iphone version, which will kick OLED production into overdrive."

Food for thought... MicroLED is likely going to grow 1000x over the coming decades. AR and LIDAR sensors for AR will probably not just be used for face unlock and will get some killer apps, the next Snapchat or TikTok might be AR based. Self-Driving is going to be powered by thousands of companies, not just NVIDIA and Waymo. Quantum computing? AI providers in the military contracting space? Clean cargo ship tech to get in front of green regulations? It's endless, and so many people know about these little niches of information that very few others do. Even mundane spaces see world changing innovation every day. Getting in front of a curve is inherently speculative but it is also entertaining, educational to follow through development, and can be extremely profitable.

That's my appeal for pulling a few pennies out of the ETF pile and doing some a little different, especially if you have a "wheelhouse" that you know a little bit more about.

body:
5G is going to be pushed hard.  I've done a fair bit of research on tickers that are worthwhile if it blows up as much as I think it will.  The implementation of these mesh networks could be huge for many companies.

Phone Semis - QCOM

Industrial + Vehicle Semis - NXPI

Shared Comms Infrastructure - AMT

Multi Discipline - INTC

&#x200B;

I hold positions (leaps or stonks in almost all of the above)

author: TripleBrain
body:
Now why the fuck exactly would any company that’s not the size of intel, Apple, ibm etc need 150 hosts??? You know the point of a host right? It’s to host a meeting. You really think anyone will need to host 150 meetings in the same time frame? Hell no.

And aside from that, you know these are not gonna be large companies because they won’t be categorizing it as “companies with 10+” employees. That’s like using inches to measure a mile. 
I’d bet a majority of those companies have under 10 hosts.

author: p_giggles
body:
I'd say that because companies which are heavily shorted are often smaller companies, there isn't a lot of other (non-financial) recognition. So if people can't find much besides a "short the shit out of this company" report, it might be more important for management to attempt to keep the stock afloat, whether it's in their own self interest or not.

If you try to short Intel it's a bit of a different story considering there are 40 analysts covering it and an ungodly amount of brand recognition. If one analyst comes out with a short and 39 say Intel is fine, it's unlikely the short piece actually does anything. But if you have three analysts covering you, which is very common for small-cap companies, one short piece can actually fuck your shit up. 

Also since companies often use their equity as collateral for a loan, the higher stock price could afford more reasonable loan terms, which could help the company's actual business.

author: boon4376
body:
When Jim Keller goes to work somewhere, you know that in 2-3 years that company will be cranking out new game changing products. Apple / AMD / Tesla.

Jim joined Intel in 2018 after leaving Tesla. Presumably to help Intel get their shit together. I'd anticipate we'll see Intel come roaring back starting in 2021.

Jim coordinates chip makers into a well oiled machine. 

Hopefully AMD's architecture and practices that Jim left in place have legs to keep up with whatever Intel develops.

author: nemoTheKid
body:
> Now why the fuck exactly would any company that’s not the size of intel, Apple, ibm etc need 150 hosts??? 

There are plenty of enterprise SaaS companies that have more than 150 sales people that aren't anywhere near the size of IBM, much less Apple. If every sales guy can host a Zoom call to talk to a prospective client, that's a host right there.

Why would you assume Zoom hosts are only for people internal to the company?

author: Shaun80
body: Some sectors are booming because of the pandemic and have huge growth potential when we emerge into our new normal post pandemic. This is especially true for technology allowing remote entertainment, medicine , commerce, payment and communication.  Netflix, E-commerce (Amazon,Shop) , Zoom video conferencing, cloud computing  (MSFT, Veev, Crm,fsly) , AI robotics (NVIDiA ,TSLA,TWLO, GOOG), 5G technology, semiconductors (AMD,TSM, QCOM, INTC) fintech (Square, Paypal, MA ,V), telemedicine (TDOC)   Brick and mortar retailers,oil , resources , REITs, financial sector will all take a hit when the economy opens to the new normal.
